'''Barclays plc''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|b|ɑːr|k|l|i|z}}, occasionally {{IPAc-en|-|l|eɪ|z}})<!--Please do not remove /r/ after /ɑː/, since Wikipedia guidelines for English Pronunciation recommend a diaphonemic transcription, an abstraction of speech sounds that accommodate General American, Received Pronunciation, Canadian English, South African, Australian, and New Zealand pronunciations; i.e. rhotic and non-rhotic pronunciations.--> is a British multinational [[universal bank]], headquartered in [[London]], England. Barclays operates as two divisions, Barclays UK and Barclays International, supported by a service company, Barclays Execution Services.<ref name="Structure and Leadership">{{cite web| url=https://home.barclays/who-we-are/structure-and-leadership/| title=Structure and Leadership| publisher=Barclays}}</ref>

Barclays traces its origins to the [[goldsmith]] banking business established in the [[City of London]] in 1690.<ref name=archives>{{citation| url=https://www.archive.barclays.com/items/show/5419| title=Barclays – A Quick History| publisher=archive.barclays.com| access-date=16 August 2017| archive-date=3 April 2019| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190403215512/https://www.archive.barclays.com/items/show/5419| url-status=dead}}</ref> James Barclay became a partner in the business in 1736. In 1896, twelve banks in London and the English provinces, including [[Goslings Bank]], [[Backhouse's Bank]] and [[Gurney's Bank|Gurney, Peckover and Company]], united as a [[joint-stock company|joint-stock]] bank under the name Barclays and Co. Over the following decades, Barclays expanded to become a nationwide bank. In 1967, Barclays deployed the world's first [[Automated teller machine|cash dispenser]]. Barclays has made numerous corporate acquisitions, including of London, Provincial and South Western Bank in 1918, [[British Linen Bank]] in 1919, Mercantile Credit in 1975, [[the Woolwich]] in 2000 and the North American operations of [[Lehman Brothers]] in 2008.<ref>{{cite news |last=Knight |first=India |date=18 September 2008 |title=Barclays' deal gives hope to UK staff of Lehman Brothers |work=[[The Times]] |location=London |url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/banking_and_finance/article4776142.ece |access-date=26 April 2010}}</ref>

Barclays has a primary listing on the [[London Stock Exchange]] and is a constituent of the [[FTSE 100 Index]]. It has a secondary listing on the [[New York Stock Exchange]]. It is considered a [[Systemically important financial institution|systemically important bank]] by the [[Financial Stability Board]].<ref>{{Cite web |date=23 November 2021 |title=2021 List of Global Systemically Important Banks (G-SIBs) |url=https://www.fsb.org/2021/11/2021-list-of-global-systemically-important-banks-g-sibs/ |access-date=20 March 2022 |website=www.fsb.org |language=en-US}}</ref> According to a 2011 paper, Barclays was the most powerful [[transnational corporation]] in terms of ownership and thus [[corporate power|corporate control]] over [[Global financial system|global financial stability]] and [[market competition]], with [[Axa]] and [[State Street Corporation]] taking the 2nd and 3rd positions, respectively.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://images.zeit.de/wissen/2012-05/s37-infografik-wirtschaft.pdf |title=Wem gehört die Welt? |access-date=16 August 2017 |url-status=dead |trans-title=Who owns the world? | work=[[Die Zeit]] |date=31 March 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161004225112/http://images.zeit.de/wissen/2012-05/s37-infografik-wirtschaft.pdf |archive-date=4 October 2016 |language=de}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal| title=The Network of Global Corporate Control| first1=Stefania| last1=Vitali| first2=James B.| last2=Glattfelder| first3=Stefano| last3=Battiston| name-list-style=amp| journal= PLOS ONE|volume = 6|issue = 10|pages = e25995| date=26 October 2011| doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0025995|pmid = 22046252|pmc = 3202517| arxiv=1107.5728|bibcode = 2011PLoSO...625995V| doi-access=free}}</ref> Barclays operates in over 40 countries, employs over 80,000 people and is the fifth largest bank in Europe by total assets.<ref name=":2">{{cite web |title=Our Firm |url=http://www.barcap.com/About+Barclays+Capital/Our+Firm |publisher=Barclays Capital}}</ref>

Barclays UK comprises the British retail banking operations, consumer credit card business, wealth management business, and corporate banking for small, medium and large-sized businesses in the UK.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Barclays |url=https://www.forbes.com/companies/barclays/ |access-date=20 March 2022 |website=Forbes |language=en}}</ref> Barclays International consists of Barclays Corporate and Investment Bank (formerly known as '''Barclays Capital''') and the Consumer, Cards & Payments business. The [[investment banking]] business provides advisory, financing and [[risk management]] services to large companies, institutions and government clients. It is a [[Primary dealers|primary dealer]] in [[Gilt-edged securities|Gilts]], [[Treasury security|U.S. Treasury securities]] and various European [[Government bond]]s.

==Name==
The name of the bank has never been spelled with an apostrophe (Barclay's), it being first registered in 1896 as "Barclay and Company, Limited", which was changed to "Barclays Bank Limited" in 1917, and to "Barclays Bank PLC" in 1982.<ref>{{cite book |last= Barfoot |first= C. C. |title= Trouble with the Apostrophe: Or, 'You Know What Hairdresser's Are Like' Language usage and description: Studies presented to N.E. Osselton on the occasion of his retirement |year= 1991 |pages= 129–130 |editor1= Ingrid Tieken-Boon van Ostade |editor2= John Frankis |publisher= Rodopi |location= Amsterdam – Atlanta, GA |isbn= 9051833121 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=ww3cSZGVgoUC&pg=PA129 |access-date= 30 May 2022}}</ref>

==History==
===1690 to 1900===
[[File:Barclays and Co. cheque. For 39 pounds, 4 shillings, and 2 pence. Issued in London by Messrs Barclay and Tritton, 1793. On display at the British Museum in London.jpg|thumb|Barclays and Co. cheque for 39 pounds, 4 shillings, and 2 pence<!-- ({{Inflation|UK|{{£sd|l=39|s=4|d=2}}|1793|fmt=eq}})-->, issued in London by Messrs Barclay and Tritton, 1793, on display at the British Museum in London]]

Barclays traces its origins back to 17 November 1690, when [[John Freame]], a [[Quaker]], and Thomas Gould, started trading as [[goldsmith banker]]s in [[Lombard Street, London]]. The name "Barclays" became associated with the business in 1736, when Freame's son-in-law James Barclay became a partner.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aboutbarclays.co.uk/content/detail.asp?NewsAreaID=138 |access-date=30 January 2007 |title=Company History |work=Barclays Newsroom: Business History |publisher=Barclays |archive-date=31 January 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090131173344/http://www.aboutbarclays.co.uk/content/detail.asp?NewsAreaID=138 |url-status=dead }} See also: ''Barclays: The Business of Banking, 1690–1996'' by Margaret Ackrill and [[Leslie Hannah]]; Cambridge UP, 2001 {{ISBN|0-521-79035-2}}</ref> In 1728, the bank moved to 54 Lombard Street, identified by the "Sign of the Black Spread [[Eagle (heraldry)|Eagle]]", which in subsequent years would become a core part of the bank's visual identity.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aboutbarclays.co.uk/content/detail.asp?NewsAreaID=138 |access-date=11 May 2008 |title=Company History |work=Barclays.lk – About us: Our History {{!}} 1690–1972 |publisher=Barclays |archive-date=31 January 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090131173344/http://www.aboutbarclays.co.uk/content/detail.asp?NewsAreaID=138 |url-status=dead }}</ref>

The Barclay family were connected with slavery, both as proponents and opponents. David and Alexander Barclay were engaged in the slave trade in 1756.<ref>{{cite book |last=Williams |first=Eric |date=1964 |title=Slavery and Capitalism |location=London |publisher= Deutsch|page=116 }}</ref> [[David Barclay of Youngsbury]] (1729–1809), on the other hand, was a noted [[abolitionism in the United Kingdom|abolitionist]], and [[Verene Shepherd]], the [[history of Jamaica|Jamaican historian]] of [[diaspora studies]], singles out the case of how he chose to [[manumission|free his slaves]] in [[English Jamaica|that colony]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Shepherd|first1=Verene|title=Freedom in the era of slavery: The case of the Barclay brothers in Jamaica|url=http://old.jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20080224/news/news3.html|access-date=15 January 2018|publisher=The Gleaner|date=24 February 2008}}</ref>

In 1776, the firm was styled "Barclay, Bevan and Bening" and remained so until 1785, when another partner, John Tritton, who had married a Barclay, was admitted, and the business then became "Barclay, Bevan, Bening and Tritton".<ref>Gamble 1923, 46.</ref> In 1896, twelve houses in London and the English provinces, notably [[Goslings Bank|Goslings and Sharpe]], [[Backhouse's Bank]] of [[Darlington]]<ref>{{cite book| first1=Margaret| last1=Ackrill| first2=Leslie| last2=Hannah | author2-link = Leslie Hannah | title=Barclays: The Business of Banking, 1690-1996| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yAwipk34KP0C| year=2001| publisher=Cambridge University Press| isbn=978-0-521-79035-2| page=57}}</ref> and [[Gurney's Bank]] of [[Norwich]] (the latter two of which also had their roots in Quaker families), united to form Barclays and Co., a [[joint-stock company|joint-stock]] bank, which at its formation held around one quarter of deposits in English private banks.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.heritagecity.org/research-centre/industrial-innovation/the-gurney-family-and-banking-in-norwich.htm| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100717225313/http://www.heritagecity.org/research-centre/industrial-innovation/the-gurney-family-and-banking-in-norwich.htm| url-status=dead| archive-date=17 July 2010| title=The Gurney family and banking in Norwich| publisher=Heritage City| access-date=19 March 2016}}</ref>

=== 1900 to 1945 ===
[[File:Northward view from top of The Monument, London, 1981-geograph-4640018-by-Ben-Brooksbank.jpg|thumb|The longstanding head office of Barclays on the corner of [[Lombard Street, London|Lombard Street]] and [[Gracechurch Street]] (lower left) before its demolition in the late 1980s]]
[[File:1 Crossroads Sutton Surrey London.JPG|thumb|Barclays branch in [[Sutton, London|Sutton]], southern Greater London, which was originally a branch of London and Provincial prior to acquisition by Barclays]]

Between 1905 and 1916, Barclays extended its branch network by making acquisitions of small English banks. Further expansion followed in 1918 when Barclays amalgamated with the [[London, Provincial and South Western Bank]], and in 1919, when the [[British Linen Bank]] was acquired by Barclays, although the British Linen Bank retained a separate board of directors and continued to issue its own banknotes (see [[Banknotes of the pound sterling]]).<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.stirlingarchives.scot/2016/02/15/bank-and-agents-house-british-linen-bank-balfron-1923/| title=Bank and Agent's House, British Linen Bank| date=15 February 2016| publisher=Stirling Archives| access-date=19 March 2016}}</ref>

{{anchor|Barclays DCO}}
In 1925, the [[Colonial Bank (West Indies)|Colonial Bank]], [[National Bank of South Africa]] and the [[Anglo-Egyptian Bank]] were amalgamated and Barclays operated its overseas operations under the name Barclays Bank (Dominion, Colonial and Overseas)—Barclays DCO.<ref name=pohl/> In 1938, Barclays acquired the first Indian exchange bank, the Central Exchange Bank of India, which had opened in London in 1936 with the sponsorship of [[Central Bank of India]].<ref>Raychaudhuri ''et al.'', eds. (1983), Vol. 2, p.782.</ref>

In 1941, during the German [[occupation of France]], a branch of Barclays in Paris, headed by Marcel Cheradame, worked directly with the invading force.<ref name=Cheradame>{{cite web| url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/1999/mar/28/theobserver7| title=Holocaust shame of Barclays| work=The Guardian| date=28 March 1999| access-date=1 January 2019}}</ref> Senior officials at the bank volunteered the names of Jewish employees, as well as ceding an estimated one hundred Jewish bank accounts to the German occupiers.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/237392.stm| title=Barclays to compensate Jews | work=BBC News| access-date=1 January 2019}}</ref> The Paris branch used its funds to increase the operational power of a large quarry that helped produce steel for the Germans. There was no evidence of contact between the head office in London and the branch in Paris during the occupation. Marcel Cheradame was kept as the branch manager until he retired in the sixties.<ref name=Cheradame/>

===1946 to 1980===
In May 1958, Barclays was the first UK bank to appoint a female bank manager. [[Hilda Harding]] managed Barclays' Hanover Square branch in London until her retirement in 1970.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.archive.barclays.com/items/show/662 |title=Head Office Circular announcing the appointment of Hilda Harding as branch manager |publisher=Barclays |date=15 May 1958 |access-date=25 September 2015 |archive-date=25 September 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925054807/https://www.archive.barclays.com/items/show/662 |url-status=dead }}</ref>

[[File:Atmplaque.jpg|thumb|right|A plaque in [[Enfield Town|Enfield]], United Kingdom commemorating the installation of the world's first [[Automated teller machine|cash machine]] by Barclays in 1967]]

In 1965, Barclays established a US affiliate, Barclays Bank of California, in [[San Francisco]].<ref>{{cite news| work=Investors chronicle and stock exchange gazette| date=5 December 1969| volume=10| page=922| title=Barclays}} Accessed 4 May 2012.</ref><ref>{{cite news| author=Leith McGrandle| work=Accountancy| date=5 December 1969| volume=85| page=54 |title=Barclays}} Accessed 4 May 2012.</ref>

Barclays launched the first credit card in the UK, [[Barclaycard]], in 1966. On 27 June 1967, Barclays deployed the world's first [[automated teller machine|cash machine]], in [[Enfield Town|Enfield]]; [[Barclays Bank, Enfield]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3AQAAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA32|title=Insert card here|access-date=4 May 2012| publisher=CIO Magazine| date=July 1988}}</ref><ref name=bbc25607>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/6230194.stm |title=The man who invented the cash machine |access-date=4 May 2012 |work=BBC News |date=25 June 2007 |first=Brian |last=Milligan }}</ref> The British actor [[Reg Varney]] was the first person to use the machine.<ref name=bbc25607/>

In 1969, a planned merger with [[Martins Bank]] and [[Lloyds Bank]] was blocked by the [[Competition Commission (United Kingdom)|Monopolies and Mergers Commission]], but the acquisition of [[Martins Bank]] on its own was later permitted. Also that year, the [[British Linen Bank]] subsidiary was sold to the [[Bank of Scotland]] in exchange for a 25% stake, a transaction that became effective from 1971. Barclays DCO changed its name to Barclays Bank International in 1971.<ref name=pohl>{{cite book| author=European Association for Banking History| editor-last1=Pohl| editor-first1=Manfred| editor-last2=Freitag| editor-first2=Sabine| title=Handbook on the history of European banks| date=1994| publisher=E. Elgar| location=Aldershot, Hants, England| isbn=9781781954218| pages=1198–1199| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eXvfNDHpfWwC&q=%22barclays+bank+international%22+established&pg=PA1193|access-date=10 October 2014}}</ref>

From 1972 until 1980, a minority stake in Banca Barclays Castellini SpA, [[Milan]] was owned by the [[Castellini Baldissera|Castellini]] family. In 1980, Barclays Bank International acquired the remaining stake in Barclays Castellini from the Castellini family.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Italy {{!}} Barclays Group Archives|url=https://www.archive.barclays.com/items/show/65|access-date=14 September 2020|website=www.archive.barclays.com|archive-date=24 October 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201024054144/https://www.archive.barclays.com/items/show/65|url-status=dead}}</ref>

In August 1975, following the [[Secondary banking crisis of 1973–1975|secondary banking crash]], Barclays acquired Mercantile Credit Company.<ref>{{cite book| title=The secondary banking crisis, 1973–75: its causes and course| first1=Margaret| last1=Reid| publisher=Macmillan| year=1982| isbn=978-0-333-28376-9 |page=128| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_XmuAAAAIAAJ&q=The+secondary+banking+crisis,+1973-75:+its+causes+and+course| access-date=4 May 2012}}</ref>

===1980 to 2000s===
[[File:Londres - 54, Lombard Street.JPG|thumb|Barclays head office after reconstruction in 1992 on a design by [[GMW Architects]],<ref>{{cite web |website=Manchester History |url=https://manchesterhistory.net/architecture/1990/54lombard.html |title=54 Lombard Street, London, UK}}</ref> photographed in 2008 before subsequent remodeling]]

Barclays Bank International expanded its business in 1980 to include commercial credit and took over American Credit Corporation, renaming it Barclays American Corporation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/Barclays-plc-Company-History.html |access-date=28 March 2009 |title=Barclays plc |work=Funding Universe}}</ref>

During 1985 Barclays Bank and Barclays Bank International merged,<ref name="a2020214">MJ Larson, G Schnyder, G Westerhaus, J Wilson (2013) — [https://books.google.com/books?id=Kb7cAAAAQBAJ&dq=Barclays+Group&pg=PA53 p.53] in (Andrea Colli, Abe De Jong, Martin Jes Iversen editors) [https://books.google.com/books?id=Kb7cAAAAQBAJ&q=Barclays+Group Mapping European Corporations: Strategy, Structure, Ownership and Performance] published by [[Routledge]], 13 September 2013 {{ISBN|1135754446}}, {{ISBN|9781135754440}} - accessed 14 February 2020</ref> and as part of the corporate reorganisation the former Barclays Bank plc became a group holding company,<ref name=pohl/> renamed Barclays Group Plc,<ref name=a2020214/> and UK [[retail banking]] was integrated under the former BBI, and renamed ''Barclays Bank PLC'' from ''Barclays Bank Limited''.<ref name=pohl/>

In response to the [[Big Bang (financial markets)|Big Bang]] on the [[London Stock Exchange]], in 1986 Barclays bought UK [[stockbroker]] de Zoete & Bevan and [[Stockjobber|jobbing firm]] '''Wedd Durlacher''' (formerly Wedd Jefferson).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sas-space.sas.ac.uk/2762/ |title=Abstract – SAS-Space |date=8 February 2011 |publisher=Sas-space.sas.ac.uk |access-date=28 June 2012}}</ref> They were merged with Barclays Merchant Bank to form '''Barclays de Zoete Wedd''' (BZW).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.linkedin.com/company/bzw-barclays-de-zoete-wedd- |title=About BZW (Barclays de Zoete Wedd) |publisher=LinkedIn |access-date=23 August 2013}}</ref> Also that year Barclays sold its South African business operating under the [[First National Bank (South Africa)|Barclays National Bank]] name after protests against Barclays' involvement in South Africa and its [[apartheid]] government.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theheritageportal.co.za/article/south-africas-oldest-bank-epic-photographic-journey|title=South Africa's Oldest Bank – An epic photographic journey|publisher=The Heritage Portal|access-date=20 March 2022}}</ref>

Barclays introduced the ''Connect'' card in June 1987, the first [[debit card]] in the United Kingdom.<ref>{{cite book |title=Law of bank payments |first1=Michael |last1=Lerego |publisher=FT Law & Tax |year=1996 |isbn=978-0-7520-0037-4 |page=472 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=anVMAQAAIAAJ&q=Law+of+bank+payments+Michael+Lerego |access-date=4 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=The banking revolution: salvation or slaughter? : how technology is creating winners and losers |first1=Mark |last1=Carrington |first2=Philip |last2=Langguth |first3=Thomas |last3=Steiner |publisher=Financial Times Pitman |year=1997 |isbn=978-0-273-63055-5 |page=119 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fid2QgAACAAJ&q=The+banking+revolution:+salvation+or+slaughter |access-date=4 May 2012}} {{Dead link |date=March 2017}}</ref>

In 1988, Barclays sold Barclays Bank of California, which at that time was the 17th-largest bank in California measured by assets, to [[Wells Fargo]] for US$125 million in cash.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/01/16/business/company-news-wells-fargo-to-buy-barclays-in-california.html |title=Wells Fargo to Buy Barclays in California |access-date=4 May 2012 |work=The New York Times |date=16 January 1988 |first=Lawrence M. |last=Fisher}}</ref>

[[Edgar Pearce]], the "Mardi Gra Bomber", began a terror campaign against the bank and the supermarket chain [[Sainsbury's]] in 1994.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/318913.stm |title=Mardi Gra bomber jailed |work=BBC News |date=14 April 1999 |access-date=18 April 2011}}</ref>

Barclays bought Wells Fargo Nikko Investment Advisors (WFNIA) in 1996 and merged it with BZW Investment Management to form [[Barclays Global Investors]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/19/business/barclays-may-soon-purchase-wells-fargo-nikko.html |title=Barclays may well soon buy Wells Fargo Nikko |work=The New York Times |date=19 June 1995 |access-date=18 April 2011}}</ref> [[Bob Diamond (banker)|Bob Diamond]] took charge of the investment banking businesses that year.<ref>[http://group.barclays.com/About-us/Management-structure/The-Board/Biography/1225802845162.html Bob Diamond] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090726113910/http://group.barclays.com/About-us/Management-structure/The-Board/Biography/1225802845162.html |date=26 July 2009 }}</ref>

Two years later, in 1998, the BZW business was broken up and the Equity and Corporate Finance Divisions were sold to [[Credit Suisse First Boston]]: Barclays retained the debt-focused Fixed Income business and Structured Capital Markets which formed the foundation of the rebranded Barclays Capital ('''BarCap''').<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-4885056.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121102215642/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-4885056.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=2 November 2012 |title=Revealed: what Credit Suisse really thinks about BZW |date=14 November 1997 |access-date=18 April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=About BZW (Barclays de Zoete Wedd) |url=http://www.linkedin.com/company/bzw-barclays-de-zoete-wedd- |access-date=23 August 2013 |publisher=LinkedIn}}</ref> Barclays Capital had offices in over 29 countries and employed over 20,000 people, with over 7,000 people working in its [[Information technology|IT]] division.<ref name=":2" />

In 1998, Barclays Bank agreed to pay $3.6m to Jews whose assets were seized from French branches of the British-based bank during World War II.<ref name="bbc">{{cite news| title=Barclays to Compensate Jews| work=[[BBC News]]| publisher=BBC.com| date=17 December 1998| access-date=13 September 2013| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/237392.stm}}</ref> Barclays, along with seven French banks, was named in a lawsuit filed in New York on behalf of Jews who were unable to reclaim money they deposited during the Nazi era.<ref name="bbc"/>

In an unusual move as part of the trend at the time for [[free ISP]]s, Barclays launched an internet service in 1999 called Barclays.net. This entity was acquired by [[British Telecom]] in 2001.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.barclays.net |title=Barclays webpage |access-date=18 April 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070517045409/http://www.barclays.net/ |archive-date=17 May 2007 }}</ref>

In the 1990s, Barclays helped to fund President [[Robert Mugabe]]'s government in [[Zimbabwe]].<ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article2848046.ece Barclays bankrolls Mugabe’s brutal regime]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081007172946/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article2848046.ece |date=7 October 2008}}.</ref> The most controversial of a set of loans provided by Barclays was the £30 million it gave to help sustain land reforms that saw Mugabe seize white-owned farmland and drive more than 100,000 black workers from their homes. Opponents have called the bank's involvement a "disgrace" and an "insult" to the millions who have suffered human rights abuses.<ref>{{cite news |first1=Antony |last1=Barnett |first2=Christopher |last2=Thompson |url=https://www.theguardian.com/money/2007/jan/28/accounts.Zimbabwenews |title=Barclays' millions help to prop up Mugabe regime |work=The Guardian |location=Manchester |date=28 January 2007 |access-date=18 April 2011}}</ref> A Barclays spokesman said the bank has had customers in Zimbabwe for decades and abandoning them now would make matters worse, "We are committed to continuing to provide a service to those customers in what is clearly a difficult operating environment".<ref>{{cite news |last=Macleod |first=Murdo |url=http://news.scotsman.com/zimbabwe/Barclays-helping-to-fund-Mugabe.3497546.jp |title=Barclays' 'helping to fund Mugabe regime' |work=The Scotsman |date=11 November 2007 |access-date=18 April 2011 |location=Edinburgh}}</ref> Barclays also provided two of Mugabe's associates with bank accounts, ignoring European Union sanctions on Zimbabwe.<ref>{{cite web|last=Macleod |first=Murdo |url=http://scotlandonsunday.scotsman.com/zimbabwe/Barclays-helping-to-fund-Mugabe.3497546.jp |title=Barclays 'helping to fund Mugabe regime' |work=The Scotsman |access-date=18 April 2011}}</ref> The men are Elliot Manyika and minister of public service Nicholas Goche. Barclays has defended its position by insisting that the EU rules do not apply to its 67%-owned Zimbabwean subsidiary because it was incorporated outside the EU.<ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/africa/article4232283.ece Robert Mugabe henchmen backed by Barclays] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604144412/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/africa/article4232283.ece |date=4 June 2011 }}</ref>

In August 2000, Barclays took over the recently de-mutualised Woolwich PLC, formerly [[the Woolwich]] Building Society,<ref>{{Cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/875639.stm |title= Barclays buys rival Woolwich |work= BBC News |date= 11 August 2000 |access-date= 18 April 2011}}</ref> in a £5.4 billion acquisition. Woolwich thus joined the Barclays group of companies, and the Woolwich name was retained after the acquisition. The company's head office remained in [[Bexleyheath]], south-east [[London]], {{Convert | 4 | mi | 0 | spell = in}} from the original head office in [[Woolwich]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/875639.stm Barclays buys rival Woolwich]. ===Abandoned merger with ABN AMRO===
In March 2007, Barclays announced plans to merge with [[ABN AMRO]], the largest bank in the Netherlands.<ref>{{cite press release |date=20 March 2007 |url=http://www.newsroom.barclays.co.uk/content/Detail.asp?ReleaseID=985&NewsAreaID=2 |title=Barclays and ABN AMRO Announce Outline of Preliminary Discussions |publisher=Barclays |access-date=18 April 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090107012336/http://www.newsroom.barclays.co.uk/content/Detail.asp?ReleaseID=985&NewsAreaID=2 |archive-date=7 January 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Werdigier |first=Julia |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/03/19/business/19deal.html |title=Barclays Bank Makes Inquiry on Takeover of ABN Amro |work=The New York Times |date=19 March 2007 |access-date=2 February 2012}}</ref> However, on 5 October 2007 Barclays announced that it had abandoned its bid,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/low/business/7029297.stm |title=Barclays abandons ABN Amro offer |work=BBC News |date=5 October 2007 |access-date=18 April 2011}}</ref> citing inadequate support by ABN shareholders. Fewer than 80% of shares had been tendered to Barclays' cash-and-shares offer.<ref>{{cite news |last=Mollenkamp |first=Carrick |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB119158340445950068?mod=googlenews_wsj |title=Barclays's CEO Shifts to Plan B |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=3 February 2011 |access-date=18 April 2011 |url-access=subscription }}</ref> This left the consortium led by [[NatWest Group|Royal Bank of Scotland Group]] free to proceed with its counter-bid for ABN AMRO.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cityam.com/index.php?news=8833 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090125174939/http://www.cityam.com/index.php?news=8833 |url-status=dead |archive-date=25 January 2009 |title=Does RBS's acquisition of ABN AMRO really do what it says on the tin? |work=[[City A.M.]] |access-date=18 April 2011}}</ref>

To help finance its bid for ABN AMRO, Barclays sold a 3.1% stake to [[China Development Bank]] and a 3% stake to [[Temasek Holdings]], the investment arm of the Singaporean government.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/news/story/barclays-looks-east-fund-new/story.aspx?guid=%7B273CEEA5-1246-44E0-B0B4-B1AAC48C312B%7D |title=Barclays looks East to fund ABN AMRO purchase |work=[[MarketWatch]] |date=23 July 2007 |access-date=18 April 2011}}</ref>

Also in 2007, Barclays agreed to purchase Equifirst Corporation from [[Regions Financial Corporation]] for US$225 million.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9501E7D71E30F933A15752C0A9619C8B63 |title=Barclays to buy sub-prime lender |work=The New York Times |date=20 January 2007 |access-date=18 April 2011}}</ref> That year also saw Barclays Personal Investment Management announcing the closure of their operation in Peterborough and its re-siting to Glasgow, laying off nearly 900 members of staff.<ref>{{cite news |date=8 May 2014 |work=BBC News |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-27321589/ |title=Barclays To Cut 19,000 Jobs Over Three Years |access-date=17 July 2014}}</ref>

===Financing===
On 30 August 2007, Barclays was forced to borrow £1.6 billion (US$3.2 billion) from the [[Bank of England]] sterling standby facility. This is made available as a last-resort when banks are unable to settle their debts to other banks at the end of daily trading.<ref>{{cite news |first1=Ashley |last1=Seager |first2=Larry |last2=Elliott |first3=Julia |last3=Kollewe |name-list-style=amp|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2007/aug/31/money |title=Barclays admits borrowing hundreds of millions |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date= 31 August 2007 |access-date=18 April 2011}}</ref> Despite rumours about liquidity at Barclays, the loan was necessary due to a technical problem with their computerised settlement network. A Barclays spokesman was quoted as saying "There are no liquidity issues in the U.K markets. Barclays itself is flush with liquidity."<ref>{{cite news |last=Menon |first=Jon |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601102&sid=aqA8hFXWD3JY&refer=uk |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930055730/http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601102&sid=aqA8hFXWD3JY&refer=uk |url-status=dead |archive-date=30 September 2007 |title=UK & Ireland |publisher=Bloomberg |date=31 August 2007 |access-date=18 April 2011}}</ref>

On 9 November 2007, Barclays shares dropped 9% and were even temporarily suspended for a short period of time, due to rumours of a £4.8 billion (US$10 billion) exposure to bad debts in the US. However, a Barclays spokesman denied the rumours.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7087451.stm |title=Barclays denies bad debt rumour |work=BBC News |date=9 November 2007 |access-date=18 April 2011}}</ref>

In February 2008, Barclays bought the credit card brand Goldfish for US$70 million gaining 1.7 million customers, and US$3.9 billion in receivables.<ref>{{cite news|
 url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/banking_and_finance/article3330860.ece| title=Barclays buys Goldfish as US Group calls time on credit cards| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611162430/http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/banking_and_finance/article3330860.ece |date=8 February 2008 |archive-date=11 June 2011 |first1=Miles |last1=Costello |first2=Siobhan |last2=Kennedy |work=[[The Times]] |url-access=subscription }}</ref> Barclays also bought a controlling stake in the Russian retail bank Expobank for US$745 million.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/banking_and_finance/article3473418.ece| title=Barclays seals Expobank deal in Russia| work=The Times| first1=Miles |last1=Costello| date=3 March 2008| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081008015533/http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/banking_and_finance/article3473418.ece |archive-date=8 October 2008}}</ref> Later in the year Barclays commenced its [[Pakistan]] operations with initial funding of US$100 million.<ref>{{cite news| work=Pakistan Daily| url=http://www.daily.pk/business/businessnews/6078.html?task=view| title=Barclays Bank UK commences operation in Pakistan| date=25 July 2008| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080912123124/http://www.daily.pk/business/businessnews/6078.html?task=view |archive-date=12 September 2008}}</ref>

Barclays sought to raise capital privately, avoiding direct equity investment from the UK government, which was offered to boost its capital ratio.<ref>{{cite news |last=Lee |first=Peter |url=http://www.euromoney.com/Article/2225039/Barclays-keeps-apologizing-for-saving-the-bank.html |title=Barclays keeps apologizing for saving the bank |work=[[Euromoney]]}}</ref> Barclays believed that "maintaining its independence from government was in the best interests of its shareholders".<ref>{{cite news |date=2 April 2013 |work=The Wall Street Journal |url=http://online.wsj.com/public/resources/documents/SalzReview04032013.pdf |title=An Independent Review of Barclays' Business Practices |access-date=25 April 2014 |url-access=subscription }}</ref>

Only 19% of shareholders took up their rights leaving investors [[China Development Bank]] and [[Qatar Investment Authority]] with increased holdings in the bank.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7513178.stm |title=Barclays share sale raises £4.5bn |work=BBC News |date=18 July 2008 |access-date=18 April 2011}}</ref>

[[Reuters]] reported in October 2008 that the [[HM Treasury|British government]] would inject £40 billion (US$69 billion) into three banks including Barclays, which might seek over £7 billion.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/innovationNewsIndustryMaterialsAndUtilities/idUSTRE49B37P20081012?sp=true |title=British banks set for 40 billion pound rescue: sources |work=Reuters |date=12 October 2008 |first1=John |last1=Bowker |first2=Ralph |last2=Gowling |access-date=18 April 2011}}</ref> Barclays later confirmed that it rejected the Government's offer and would instead raise £6.5 billion of new capital (£2 billion by cancellation of dividend and £4.5 billion from private investors).<ref name=nytqatar/><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bankingtimes.co.uk/13102008-barclays-confirms-65bn-fundraising/| title=Barclays confirms £6.5bn fundraising|

Barclays launched a further round of capital raising, approved by special resolution on 24 November 2008, as part of its overall plan to achieve higher capital targets set by the UK's [[Financial Services Authority]] to ensure it would remain independent.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.euromoney.com/Article/2038377/Abigail-Hofman-The-loser-list.html#strategy |title=Abigail Hofman: The loser list |work=Euromoney |date=30 October 2008}}</ref> Barclays raised £7 billion from investors from Abu Dhabi and Qatar.<ref name=nytqatar>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/01/business/worldbusiness/01barclays.html |title=Barclays Seeks $11.8 Billion From Abu Dhabi and Qatar |date=1 November 2008 |work=The New York Times |access-date=19 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.euromoney.com/Article/2059789/Abigail-with-attitude-More-zeroes-than-heroes.html#barclays |title=Abigail Hofman: More zeroes than heroes – Barclays |work=Euromoney |date=1 December 2008}}</ref> Existing Barclays shareholders complained they were not offered full pre-emption rights in this round of capital raising, even threatening to revolt at the extraordinary meeting. Sheikh Mansour and Qatar Holding agreed to open up £500 million of their new holdings of reserve capital instruments for [[clawback]]. Existing investors now took this up.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.euromoney.com/Article/3198818/Barclays-Qatari-capital-raising-timeline.html |title=Barclays' Qatari capital-raising timeline |work=Euromoney |first=Erica |last=Jeffery |date=12 May 2014}}</ref>

===Lehman Brothers acquisition===
[[File:Lehman Brothers Times Square by David Shankbone.jpg|thumb|The former headquarters of [[Lehman Brothers]] in New York City, now owned by Barclays]]
[[File:BBNY.jpg|right|thumb|300px|The New York building at night]]
Bob Diamond led the effort to purchase the North American business of [[Lehman Brothers]] after its bankruptcy in September 2008, securing Barclays a presence in U.S. Equities and Investment Banking.<ref>{{Cite news |author1=Howard Mustoe |author2=Ambereen Choudhury |date=24 April 2013 |title=Barclays Reaps Benefit of Diamond's Purchase of Lehman in U.S. |publisher=[[Bloomberg News]] |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-04-24/barclays-reaps-benefit-of-diamond-s-purchase-of-lehman-in-u-s-.html}}</ref> On 16 September 2008, Barclays announced its agreement to purchase, subject to regulatory approval, the investment-banking and trading divisions of [[Lehman Brothers]] (including its New York skyscraper) which was a United States financial conglomerate that had filed for bankruptcy.<ref>{{cite news| last=Treanor| first=Jill| title=Barclays to buy Lehman Brothers assets| url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2008/sep/16/barclay.lehmanbrothers1| newspaper=The Guardian| date=16 April 2013| location=London}}</ref>

On 20 September 2008, a revised version of the deal, a US$1.35 billion (£700 million) plan for Barclays to acquire the core business of Lehman Brothers (mainly Lehman's US$960 million [[Midtown Manhattan]] office skyscraper, with responsibility for 9,000 former employees), was approved. After a seven-hour hearing, New York [[United States bankruptcy court|bankruptcy court]] Judge James Peck ruled:
{{blockquote|I have to approve this transaction because it is the only available transaction. Lehman Brothers became a victim, in effect the only true icon to fall in a tsunami that has befallen the credit markets. This is the most momentous bankruptcy hearing I've ever sat through. It can never be deemed precedent for future cases. It's hard for me to imagine a similar emergency.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7626624.stm |title=Judge approves $1.3bn Lehman deal |work=BBC News |date=20 September 2008 |access-date=18 April 2011| archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110512055650/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7626624.stm| archive-date= 12 May 2011 |url-status=live}}</ref>}}

Luc Despins, the creditors committee counsel, said: "The reason we're not objecting is really based on the lack of a viable alternative. We did not support the transaction because there had not been enough time to properly review it." In the amended agreement, Barclays would absorb US$47.4 billion in securities and assume US$45.5 billion in trading liabilities. Lehman's attorney [[Harvey R. Miller]] of [[Weil, Gotshal & Manges]], said "the purchase price for the real estate components of the deal would be US$1.29 billion, including US$960 million for Lehman's New York headquarters and US$330 million for two New Jersey data centres. Lehman's original estimate valued its headquarters at US$1.02 billion but an appraisal from CB Richard Ellis this week valued it at US$900 million." Further, Barclays will not acquire Lehman's Eagle Energy unit, but will have entities known as Lehman Brothers Canada Inc, Lehman Brothers Sudamerica, Lehman Brothers Uruguay and its Private Investment Management business for high-net-worth individuals. In September 2014, Barclays was ordered to pay $15 million in settlement charges that alleged the bank had failed to maintain an adequate internal compliance system after its acquisition of Lehman Brothers during the 2008 financial crisis.<ref>{{cite news| work=Reuters| date=23 September 2014| title=Barclays to pay $15 million over compliance failures tied to Lehman deal| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-sec-barclays-violations-idUSKCN0HI1ZE20140923}}</ref>

===Qatar capital raising===
In January 2009, the press reported that further capital may be required and that while the government might be willing to fund this, it may be unable to do so because the previous capital investment from the Qatari state was subject to a proviso that no third party might put in further money without the Qataris receiving compensation at the value the shares had commanded in October 2008.<ref>[http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/banking_and_finance/article5570035.ece John Varley perplexed as Barclays' share price dives] ''The Times'', 23 January 2009</ref> In March 2009, it was reported that in 2008, Barclays received billions of dollars from its insurance arrangements with [[American International Group|AIG]], including US$8.5 billion from funds provided by the United States to bail out AIG.<ref>{{cite news| title=Big European Banks Benefit from AIG Bailout| url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/29714822| first1=Mary| last1=Thompson| first2=Steve| last2=Liesman| date=5 August 2010| publisher=[[CNBC]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| first=Eamon| last=Javers| url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0309/20039.html| title=AIG ships billions in bailout abroad| work=[[Politico]]| date=15 March 2009}}</ref>

Barclays' share price fell 54% in June 2009 after the [[International Petroleum Investment Company]] (IPIC), which had invested up to £4.75 billion in November 2008, sold 1.3 billion Barclays shares.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.euromoney.com/Article/2231148/Euromoney-40th-anniversary-special-Focus-on-Ipic.html |title=Euromoney 40th anniversary special: Focus on Ipic | work=Euromoney |date=June 2009}}</ref>
[[Qatar Investment Authority|Qatar Holding]] sold a 3.5% stake worth £10 billion in October 2009,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.euromoney.com/Article/2350993/Abigail-with-attitude-Barclays-tea-leaves.html |title=Abigail with attitude: Barclays' tea leaves |work=Euromoney |first=Abigail |last=Hofman |date=3 December 2009}}</ref> and a further sale of warrants worth around £750 million in November 2012, but remains one of the bank's largest shareholders.<ref name="Euromoney">{{cite news| first=Erica| last=Jeffery| url=http://www.euromoney.com/Article/3198818/Barclays-Qatari-capital-raising-timeline.html |title=Barclays' Qatari capital-raising timeline |work=Euromoney |date=12 May 2014}}</ref> In July 2012, Barclays revealed that the FSA was investigating<ref name="Euromoney"/> whether the bank adequately disclosed fees paid to [[Qatar Investment Authority]]. In August 2012, the [[Serious Fraud Office (United Kingdom)|Serious Fraud Office]] announced an investigation into the Middle East capital raising. The [[Financial Services Authority]] announced an expansion of the investigation into the Barclays-Qatar deal in January 2013, focusing on the disclosure surrounding the ownership of the securities in the bank.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/47d412ce-6bd1-11e2-a700-00144feab49a.html |title=Barclays in Qatar loan probe |work=Financial Times |date=31 January 2013 |url-access=subscription }}</ref>

Barclays' June and November 2008 capital raisings are the subject of investigations.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.euromoney.com/Article/3198818/Category/17/ChannelPage/0/Barclays-Qatari-capital-raising-timeline.html |title=Barclays' Qatari capital-raising timeline |work=Euromoney |date=21 May 2013}}</ref>
The UK's [[Serious Fraud Office (United Kingdom)|Serious Fraud Office]] commenced its investigation in August 2012. In October 2012, the [[United States Department of Justice]] and the [[US Securities and Exchange Commission]] informed Barclays they had commenced an investigation into whether the group's relationships with third parties who assist Barclays to win or retain business are compliant with the US [[Foreign Corrupt Practices Act]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://reports.barclays.com/ar12/financialstatements/notes/accrualsprovisionslegalproceedingsandcontingentliabilities/30competitionandregulatorymatters.html |title=30 Competition and regulatory matters – Annual Report 2012 |publisher=Barclays.com |access-date=23 May 2013 |archive-date=3 February 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203133114/http://reports.barclays.com/ar12/financialstatements/notes/accrualsprovisionslegalproceedingsandcontingentliabilities/30competitionandregulatorymatters.html |url-status=dead }}</ref>

Barclays had sought to raise capital privately, avoiding direct equity investment from the [[Government of the United Kingdom]] and, therefore, a bailout. The result was Abu Dhabi's £3.5 billion investment in the bank, a deal in which [[Sheikh Mansour bin Zayed al Nahyan]] made a profit of £3.5 billion.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.euromoney.com/Article/3198637/Category/17/ChannelPage/0/Revealed-The-truth-about-Barclays-and-the-Abu-Dhabi-investment.html |title=Revealed: The truth about Barclays and the Abu Dhabi investment |publisher=Euromoney.com |date=30 April 2013}}</ref>
Much of the focus to date has been on the injections by Qatar in June and November 2008, notably the so far unproven allegation that Barclays lent Qatar the money to invest in the bank. In June 2017, following a five-year investigation by the UK's [[Serious Fraud Office (United Kingdom)|Serious Fraud Office]] covering Barclays' activities during the [[financial crisis of 2007–2008]], former CEO [[John Silvester Varley|John Varley]] and three former colleagues, [[Roger Jenkins (banker)|Roger Jenkins]], [[Thomas Kalaris]] and [[Richard Boath]], were charged with [[Conspiracy to defraud|conspiracy to commit fraud]] and the provision of [[Financial assistance (share purchase)|unlawful financial assistance]] in connection with capital raising.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-40338220 |title=Barclays charged with fraud in Qatar case |work=BBC News |date=1 January 1970 |access-date=20 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Jill |last=Treanor |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2017/jun/20/sfo-charges-barclays-bank-executives-ceo-2008-qatar-fundraising |title=Senior Barclays bankers charged with fraud over credit crunch fundraising |work=The Guardian |date=1 January 1970 |access-date=20 June 2017}}</ref> The executives were cleared in February 2020.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-51673470|title=Former Barclays executives cleared of fraud charges|date=28 February 2020|newspaper=BBC|access-date=12 October 2022}}</ref>

In February 2018, the Serious Fraud Office charged Barclays with "unlawful financial assistance" related to billions of pounds raised from the Qatar deal.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-43029731|title=Barclays Bank charged over Qatar loans| date=12 February 2018| work=BBC News| access-date=12 February 2018| language=en-GB}}</ref>

On 8 June 2020, Barclays was also accused of deceit by a British businesswoman [[Amanda Staveley]]'s firm PCP Capital. The company sued the bank in a £1.5 billion lawsuit, claiming that it had "deliberately misled" the market over the terms of its capital raising deal with Qatar. PCP alleged that [[Qatar Holdings]] was offered a "completely different" deal than that offered to [[Mansour bin Zayed Al Nahyan]] of [[Abu Dhabi]], who according to Amanda Staveley was introduced to Barclays by PCP.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.ft.com/content/60847757-80bd-420f-9d5a-8e244f4a5520|title=Barclays 'misled' the market over Qatar deal, court told|access-date=8 June 2020|website=Financial Times|date=8 June 2020 }}</ref> However, during the hearing in the High Court of [[London]], the Barclays lawyer, Jeffery Onions accused Staveley of "significantly exaggerating" her business relationship with the Abu Dhabi sheikh and of creating a "hustle" by getting involved in a crucial capital raising.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.ft.com/content/5be8e93a-c54c-426b-8412-cb3719e291cc|title=Amanda Staveley accused of exaggerating links with Abu Dhabi|access-date=19 June 2020|website=Financial Times|date=19 June 2020 }}</ref> Staveley and PCP Capital subsequently reduced the amount of their claim but lost the case in the High Court.<ref>{{Cite news|date=26 February 2021|title=Amanda Staveley loses High Court fight with Barclays over damages|language=en-GB|work=BBC News|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-56208668|access-date=27 February 2021}}</ref>

===Accusations of money laundering===
In March 2009, Barclays was accused of violating international anti-[[money laundering]] laws. According to the NGO [[Global Witness]], the Paris branch of Barclays held the account of Equatorial Guinean President [[Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo|Teodoro Obiang]]'s son, [[Teodoro Nguema Obiang Mangue|Teodorin Obiang]], even after evidence that Obiang had siphoned oil revenues from government funds emerged in 2004. According to Global Witness, Obiang purchased a [[Ferrari]] and maintains a mansion in [[Malibu, California|Malibu]] with the funds from this account.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7936335.stm |title= Barclays 'corrupt regime' claim |access-date=9 March 2009 |last=Shankleman |first=Martin |date=11 March 2009 |work=BBC News |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090314035815/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7936335.stm |archive-date=14 March 2009| url-status=live}}</ref>

A 2010 report by the Wall Street Journal described how [[Credit Suisse]], Barclays, [[Lloyds Banking Group]], and other banks were involved in helping the [[Alavi Foundation]], [[Bank Melli Iran|Bank Melli]], the Iranian government, and/or others circumvent US laws banning financial transactions with certain states. They did this by "stripping" information out of wire transfers, thereby concealing the source of funds. Barclays settled with the government for US$298 million.<ref>"Probe Circles Globe to Find Dirty Money", Carrick Mollenkamp, ''The Wall Street Journal'', 3 September 2010.</ref>

===Rate-fixing scandal===
{{main|Libor scandal}}
In June 2012, as a result of an international investigation, Barclays Bank was fined a total of £290 million (US$450 million) for manipulating the daily settings of London Interbank Offered Rate ([[Libor]]) and the Euro Interbank Offered Rate ([[Euribor]]). The United States Department of Justice and Barclays officially agreed that "the manipulation of the submissions affected the fixed rates on some occasions".<ref name="usdoj statement of facts">{{cite web| url=https://www.justice.gov/iso/opa/resources/9312012710173426365941.pdf | title=Statement of Facts| publisher=United States Department of Justice| date=26 June 2012| access-date=11 July 2012}}</ref> The bank was found to have made 'inappropriate submissions' of rates which formed part of the Libor and Euribor setting processes, sometimes to make a profit, and other times to make the bank look more secure during the financial crisis.<ref name=bbc_libor_manipulation/> This happened between 2005 and 2009, as often as daily.<ref name=cbs_libor_manipulation/>

The [[BBC]] said revelations concerning the fraud were "greeted with almost universal astonishment in the banking industry."<ref>{{cite news| first=Ian| last=Pollock| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-18622907| title=Libor scandal: Who might have lost?| work=BBC News |date=28 June 2012| access-date=28 June 2012}}</ref> The UK's [[Financial Services Authority]] (FSA), which levied a fine of £59.5 million ($92.7 million), gave Barclays the biggest fine it had ever imposed in its history.<ref name=cbs_libor_manipulation>{{cite news| url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-505123_162-57462315/barclays-to-pay-$453m-for-attempting-to-manipulate-rates/| title=Barclays to pay largest civil fine in CFTC history| work=CBS News| date=27 June 2012| access-date=27 June 2012}}</ref> The FSA's director of enforcement described Barclays' behaviour as "completely unacceptable", adding "Libor is an incredibly important benchmark reference rate, and it is relied on for many, many hundreds of thousands of contracts all over the world."<ref name=bbc_libor_manipulation/> The bank's chief executive [[Bob Diamond (banker)|Bob Diamond]] decided to give up his bonus as a result of the fine.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/business/2012-06/28/c_123339718.htm| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120707001938/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/business/2012-06/28/c_123339718.htm| url-status=dead| archive-date=7 July 2012| title=Barclays to pay over 450 million dollars to settle charges regarding LIBOR| agency=Xinhua News Agency| date=27 June 2012| access-date=27 June 2012}}</ref> [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrat]] politician [[Lord Oakeshott]] criticised Diamond, saying: "If he had any shame he would go. If the Barclays board has any backbone, they'll sack him."<ref name=bbc_libor_manipulation>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-18612279|title=Barclays fined for attempts to manipulate Libor rates |work=BBC News |date=27 June 2012 |access-date=27 June 2012}}</ref> The US Department of Justice has also been involved, with "other financial institutions and individuals" under investigation.<ref name=bbc_libor_manipulation/>

On 2 July 2012, Marcus Agius resigned from the chairman position following the interest rate rigging scandal.<ref>{{cite news |agency=Reuters |title=Barclays chairman resigns over interest rate rigging scandal |url=http://profit.ndtv.com/News/Article/barclays-chairman-to-resign-over-interest-rate-rigging-scandal-307175 |access-date=2 July 2012 |newspaper=NDTV profit |date=2 July 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120704215734/http://profit.ndtv.com/News/Article/barclays-chairman-to-resign-over-interest-rate-rigging-scandal-307175 |archive-date=4 July 2012 }}</ref> On 3 July 2012, Bob Diamond resigned with immediate effect, leaving Marcus Agius to fill his post until a replacement is found.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-18685040 |title=Barclays boss Bob Diamond resigns amid Libor scandal |work=BBC News |date=3 July 2012 |access-date=30 July 2012}}</ref> Within the space of a few hours, this was followed by the resignation of the Bank's chief operating officer, Jerry del Missier.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://business.inquirer.net/68943/bob-diamond-quits-as-barclays-ceo |title=Bob Diamond quits as Barclays CEO |newspaper=Philippine Daily Inquirer |date=4 July 2012 |access-date=25 April 2014}}</ref> Barclays subsequently announced that Antony Jenkins, its existing chief executive of Global Retail & Business Banking would become group chief executive on 30 August 2012.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=25068045&ticker=BARC:LN |title=Executive Profile Antony P. ===Gold price manipulation===

===US lawsuit alleging dark pool fraud===
In June 2014, the US state of New York filed a lawsuit against the bank alleging it defrauded and deceived investors with inaccurate marketing material about its unregulated trading system known as a ''[[dark pool]]''. Specifically, the firm was accused of hiding the fact that [[Tradebot]] participated in the dark pool when they were in fact one of the largest players. The state, in its complaint, said it was being assisted by former Barclays executives and it was seeking unspecified damages. The bank's shares dropped 5% on news of the lawsuit, prompting an announcement to the [[London Stock Exchange]] by the bank saying it was taking the allegations seriously, and was co-operating with the [[New York attorney general]].<ref name="BarclaysVsNY">{{cite news| title=Dark pool fraud lawsuit filed against Barclays in US| url=http://www.newyorktelegraph.com/index.php/sid/223293195/scat/3a8a80d6f705f8cc/ht/Dark-pool-fraud-lawsuit-filed-against-Barclays-in-US| archive-url=https://archive.today/20140628010744/http://www.newyorktelegraph.com/index.php/sid/223293195/scat/3a8a80d6f705f8cc/ht/Dark-pool-fraud-lawsuit-filed-against-Barclays-in-US| url-status=dead| archive-date=28 June 2014| date=27 June 2014| work=New York Telegraph| access-date=16 August 2017}}</ref>

A month later the bank filed a motion for the suit to be dismissed, saying there had been no fraud, no victims and no harm to anyone. The New York Attorney General's office issued a statement saying the attorney general was confident the motion would fail.<ref name="BarclaysDefense">{{cite news| title=Barclays seeks dismissal of New York dark pool suit| url=http://www.thelondonnews.net/index.php/sid/224095831/scat/3a8a80d6f705f8cc/ht/Barclays-seeks-dismissal-of-New-York-dark-pool-suit| archive-url=https://archive.today/20140806065744/http://www.thelondonnews.net/index.php/sid/224095831/scat/3a8a80d6f705f8cc/ht/Barclays-seeks-dismissal-of-New-York-dark-pool-suit| url-status=dead| archive-date=6 August 2014| access-date=25 July 2014| publisher=The London News.Net}}</ref> On 31 January 2016, Barclays settled with both the New York Attorney General's office and the SEC, agreeing to pay $70 million split evenly between the SEC and New York state, admitting it violated securities laws and agreeing to install an independent monitor for the dark pool.<ref name="BarclaysSettlement">{{cite news| title=Barclays, Credit Suisse strike record deals with SEC, NY over dark pools| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/sec-new-york-darkpools-idUSL2N15G0KS| access-date=1 February 2015| publisher=Reuters}}</ref>

=== Climate change ===
In 2017, Barclays faced protests by environmentalists because of its ownership of [[Third Energy Onshore]] which planned to extract natural gas using [[hydraulic fracturing]] (fracking) at [[Kirby Misperton]] in Yorkshire. Barclays later sold Third Energy in 2020 to Alpha Energy.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Kleinman |first1=Mark |title=Barclays-backed fracker Third Energy courts rivals for cash |url=https://news.sky.com/story/barclays-backed-fracker-third-energy-courts-rivals-for-cash-11287180 |website=Sky |access-date=2 August 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Twidale |first1=Susanna |title=Barclays to exit British gas fracking industry |url=https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-fracking/barclays-to-exit-british-gas-fracking-industry-idUKKCN1S122S |website=reuters.com |date=25 April 2019 |access-date=2 August 2020}}</ref>

Between 2016 and 2021, Barclays along with HSBC, Santander, NatWest and Lloyds Bank funnelled $368 billion into the fossil fuel industry.<ref>{{cite web |title=Banking on Climate Chaos |url=https://www.bankingonclimatechaos.org/wp-content/themes/bocc-2021/inc/bcc-data-2022/BOCC_2022_vSPREAD.pdf |website=bankingonclimatechaos.org}}</ref> The Big 5 UK high street banks provided $15.7 billion in finance to the Top 50 oil and gas expanders in 2021.<ref>{{cite web |title=ShareAction |url=https://api.shareaction.org/resources/reports/Oil-Gas-Expansion-lose-lose.pdf}}</ref>

In 2020, the campaign group [[ShareAction]] filed a resolution at Barclays AGM<ref>{{cite web |last1=Wearden |first1=Graeme |title=Climate change activists target Bank of England and Barclays - business live |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2020/feb/12/barclays-pressure-fossil-fuel-loans-asset-manager-amundi |website=theguardian.com |date=12 February 2020 |access-date=2 August 2020}}</ref> because of its role as Europe's largest funder of fossil fuel companies. Barclays invested $85 billion in fossil fuel extraction and $24 billion in expansion.<ref>{{cite web |title=Banking on Climate Change – Fossil Fuel Finance Report Card 2019 |url=https://www.banktrack.org/article/banking_on_climate_change_fossil_fuel_finance_report_card_2019 |website=banktrack.org |access-date=2 August 2020}}</ref>

===Exchange-rate rigging (last-look system)===
Barclays agreed to pay $150 million to resolve an investigation by New York's banking regulator into a trading practice that allowed the bank to exploit a milliseconds-long lag between an order and its execution that sometimes hurt its clients, the latest fallout from the bank's foreign-exchange business.<ref name="WSJ_BarclaysLastLook">{{cite news| url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/barclays-to-pay-150-million-over-last-look-trading-system-1447860696| title=Barclays to Pay $150 Million Over 'Last Look' Trading System| first=Christopher M.| last=Matthews| date=18 November 2015| work=The Wall Street Journal| access-date=19 March 2016}}</ref>

In certain instances, Barclays used this [[Last look (foreign exchange)|last-look]] system to automatically reject client orders that would be unprofitable for the bank because of subsequent price swings during milliseconds-long latency ("hold") periods. Furthermore, when clients questioned Barclays about these rejected trades, Barclays failed to disclose the reason that the trades were being rejected, instead citing technical issues or providing vague responses.<ref name="NYDoFS_BarclaysLastLook">{{cite press release| title=NYDFS Announces Barclays to Pay Additional $150 Million Penalty, Terminate Employee for Automated, Electronic Foreign Exchange Trading Misconduct| publisher=New York Department of Financial Services| url=http://www.dfs.ny.gov/about/press/pr1511181.htm| date=18 November 2015| access-date=19 March 2016| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160318213118/http://www.dfs.ny.gov/about/press/pr1511181.htm| archive-date=18 March 2016| url-status=dead}}</ref>

===Unsuitable mutual fund transactions===
According to the [[Financial Industry Regulatory Authority]], Barclays' inadequate supervisory procedures failed to stop many customers from swapping one mutual fund for another when the benefits of switching might be undermined by the transaction costs, resulting in $8.63 million of losses for their customers between January 2010 and June 2015. Additionally, from March to August 2014, Barclays processed 1,723 fund transactions that were inconsistent with its customers' goals, risk tolerance or other investments which caused an additional $818,000 of customer harm. As a result, Barclays was required to pay $10 million in restitution, including interest, to affected customers and was fined $3.75 million, but did not admit or deny wrongdoing.<ref>{{cite news|title=Barclays in $13.75 mln U.S. settlement over mutual funds|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/barclays-mutualfunds-settlement-idUSL1N14I0VX20151229|access-date=1 February 2015|publisher=Reuters}}</ref>

==Operations==
Barclays operates as two divisions, Barclays UK (BUK) and Barclays International (BI), supported by a service company, Barclays Execution Services (BX).<ref name="Structure and Leadership"/> 
* Barclays UK consists of UK Personal Banking, UK Business Banking and Barclaycard Consumer UK businesses, carried on by a [[Ringfencing|UK ring-fenced bank]] (Barclays Bank UK PLC) and certain other entities within the Group. 
* Barclays International consists of the "Corporate and Investment Bank" and "Consumer, Cards and Payments" businesses, which are carried on by a nonring-fenced bank (Barclays Bank PLC) and its subsidiaries, as well as by certain other entities within the Group.
* Barclays Execution Services is the Group-wide service company providing technology, operations and functional services to businesses across the Group.
